Covariance Bell Inequalities

Victor Pozsgay DÃ©partement de Physique AppliquÃ©e, UniversitÃ© de GenÃ¨ve, 1211 GenÃ¨ve, Switzerland â€ƒâ€ƒ Flavien Hirsch DÃ©partement de Physique AppliquÃ©e, UniversitÃ© de GenÃ¨ve, 1211 GenÃ¨ve, Switzerland â€ƒâ€ƒ Cyril Branciard Univ. Grenoble Alpes, CNRS, Grenoble INP111Institute of Engineering Univ. Grenoble Alpes, Institut NÃ©el, 38000 Grenoble, France â€ƒâ€ƒ Nicolas Brunner DÃ©partement de Physique AppliquÃ©e, UniversitÃ© de GenÃ¨ve, 1211 GenÃ¨ve, Switzerland
(3rdÂ March 2024)
Abstract

We introduce Bell inequalities based on covariance, one of the most common measures of correlation. Explicit examples are discussed, and violations in quantum theory are demonstrated. A crucial feature of these covariance Bell inequalities is their nonlinearity; this has nontrivial consequences for the derivation of their local bound, which is not reached by deterministic local correlations. For our simplest inequality, we derive analytically tight bounds for both local and quantum correlations. An interesting application of covariance Bell inequalities is that they can act as â€œshared randomness witnessesâ€: specifically, the value of the Bell expression gives device-independent lower bounds on both the dimension and the entropy of the shared random variable in a local model.

Bell inequalities limit the strength of possible correlations for any model satisfying a natural definition of locality formulated by BellÂ bell64 . Thus, the violation of a Bell inequality indicates that no local model (in the sense of Bell) can reproduce the observed data, which is therefore said to be (Bell) nonlocal. This can be the case in quantum theory where, by performing well-chosen local measurements on an entangled quantum system, one may obtain nonlocal quantum correlations.

Beyond their fundamental interest, Bell inequalities are widely used tools, in particular in quantum information scienceÂ review . Indeed, a Bell inequality violation represents a simple and strong test for certifying the presence of entanglement. Importantly this test is device-independent, in the sense that, assuming quantum theory, a Bell inequality violation implies the presence of entanglement without any assumption on the measuring devices, nor on the Hilbert space dimension. Moreover, the violation of a Bell inequality can also be used to certify the presence of genuine quantum randomnessÂ colbeck ; pironio , or the security of a cryptographic keyÂ acin .

Consider two separate observers, performing local measurement on a shared physical system. The experiment results in some data, namely the joint conditional probabilities of observing a pair of outputs (measurement results) given a pair of inputs (choice of measurement settings). As they capture the strength of correlations in the data, it is intuitive that Bell inequalities are constructed based on some measure of correlation. For instance, the simplest and most famous Bell inequality of Clauser-Horne-Shimony-Holt (CHSH)Â chsh is a linear combination of simple correlation functions (see below). As these correlation functions are themselves linear combinations of the joint conditional probabilities, the CHSH inequality is a so-called linear Bell inequality. More generally, it is known that the set of distributions that are Bell local can be fully characterized via linear Bell inequalitiesÂ Pitowsky89 , and great efforts have been dedicated to find such inequalities, see e.g. Refs.Â pitowsky ; sliwa ; CG ; I4422 ; tamas ; rosset .

It is however natural to ask if other measures of correlations can be used for devising Bell inequalities. Beyond the purely conceptual interest, this could be relevant in a practical context in which the full data is not available, but only certain specific (not necessarily linear) functions of the joint probabilities are. Moreover, it would be interesting to devise new types of Bell inequalities for the case of continuous measurement outcomes, for which the standard approach for constructing linear inequalities does not work anymore.

Several works have explored these ideas. First, entropic Bell inequalitiesÂ bc ; cerf ; chaves were obtained by considering the mutual information between the measurement outcomes. Later, inequalities based on higher moments of the distribution were also derivedÂ eric ; salles ; belzig ; bednorz . Finally, nonlinear Bell inequalities have been developed for discussing the generalization of Bell nonlocality to networksÂ branciard ; biloc2 ; armin ; chaves16 ; rosset16 .

Here we introduce a novel class of nonlinear Bell inequalities based on the covariance of measurement results, a natural measure of correlations that is widely used in many different areas of science. We propose a general way to construct such Bell inequalities for covariances, and present, in the simplest case, a method for computing their local boundâ€”a nontrivial problem due to the nonlinearity of the Bell expression. We show on a few explicit examples that our inequalities can detect quantum nonlocality. Moreover, we show that covariance Bell inequalities can be used to characterize shared randomness in a Bell test, providing device-independent lower bounds on the dimension and the entropy of the shared random variable in any local model.

A Bell inequality for covariances.â€”

Instead of using the correlation functions âŸ¨Axâ€‹ByâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğ´ğ‘¥subscriptğµğ‘¦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle, other quantities can also be considered to characterize local distributions; indeed, Bell inequalities were for instance constructed for entropic quantitiesÂ bc ; cerf ; chaves . In this work we focus on another natural and widely used measure of correlation, namely the covariance. As mentioned previously, this may be of practical interest for situations where the full data is not available, and only covariances can be estimated. An advantage of using covariances is also that, like entropies, they are naturally defined for any number of possible measurement outcomes, and even for continuous outcomes. Unlike entropies however, they depend on the specific values given to the measurement outcomes; this allows one, in particular, to distinguish correlations versus anti-correlations.

The covariance of the two output variables Axsubscriptğ´ğ‘¥A_{x} and Bysubscriptğµğ‘¦B_{y} is defined as

covâ€‹(Ax,By)=âŸ¨Axâ€‹ByâŸ©âˆ’âŸ¨AxâŸ©â€‹âŸ¨ByâŸ©,covsubscriptğ´ğ‘¥subscriptğµğ‘¦delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğ´ğ‘¥subscriptğµğ‘¦delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğ´ğ‘¥delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğµğ‘¦\displaystyle\text{cov}(A_{x},B_{y})=\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle-\langle A_{x}\rangle\langle B_{y}\rangle, (4)

with âŸ¨Axâ€‹ByâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğ´ğ‘¥subscriptğµğ‘¦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle defined as above, and similarly with âŸ¨AxâŸ©=âˆ‘a,baâ€‹Pâ€‹(a,b|x,y)delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğ´ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘conditionalğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\langle A_{x}\rangle=\sum_{a,b}a\,P(a,b|x,y) and âŸ¨ByâŸ©=âˆ‘a,bbâ€‹Pâ€‹(a,b|x,y)delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğµğ‘¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘conditionalğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\langle B_{y}\rangle=\sum_{a,b}b\,P(a,b|x,y) (for continuous values, the sums can simply be replaced by integrals, and the probabilities by probability density functions; note also that because of the non-signalling assumption, âŸ¨AxâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğ´ğ‘¥\langle A_{x}\rangle does not depend on yğ‘¦y, and âŸ¨ByâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğµğ‘¦\langle B_{y}\rangle does not depend on xğ‘¥x). We emphasize that because of the product term in Eq.Â (4), the covariance is a nonlinear function of the joint probabilities Pâ€‹(a,b|x,y)ğ‘ƒğ‘conditionalğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦P(a,b|x,y).

By optimizing the values of covCHSH(â€²)superscriptcovCHSHâ€²\text{covCHSH}^{(\prime)} numerically (but with reliable enough results), we obtained the local set represented in Fig.Â 1.

One immediately sees that contrary to the standard local polytope in the probability space, the local set in the covariance space is nonconvex, and that (unsurprisingly) it cannot be fully described by a finite number of Bell inequalities based on linear combinations of the covariances. Its full characterization thus looks much more complicated than that of the standard local polytope. Nevertheless, one can still derive some Bell inequalities for covariances that provide an outer approximation of the local set. As illustrated on Fig.Â 1, an example of such covariance Bell inequalities is the following:

covCHSHâ‰¤167.covCHSH167\displaystyle\text{covCHSH}\,\leq\,\frac{16}{7}\,. (6)

In order to prove that this inequality indeed holds for any local distribution, it is in fact sufficient to restrict to distributions with binary outputs Â±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1. Those can be written as convex mixtures of finitely many deterministic (local) distributions, and one can then optimize the expression covCHSH over the corresponding weights. To take into account the constraint that these weights must be nonnegative and sum up to 111, one can introduce Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) multipliersÂ KKT , which provide necessary conditions for a solution to be optimal. By considering decompositions onto different sets of deterministic distributions with nonzero weights, these KKT conditions simplify to a number of linear systems, which can easily be solved. The full details of the proof are given (together with an alternative approach) in AppendixÂ A.

It is instructive to look more closely in the proof at decompositions with a given number dğ‘‘d of deterministic distributions with nonzero weights. First note that for d=1ğ‘‘1d=1, i.e., for deterministic distributions, all covariances are 00, and therefore one also obtains covCHSH=0covCHSH0\text{covCHSH}=0. To obtain a nonzero value, one thus needs to consider mixtures of at least 2 distributions. For d=2ğ‘‘2d=2, one finds that the maximal possible value is covCHSH=2covCHSH2\text{covCHSH}=2, obtained for instance by the distribution P2=12[(++/+âˆ’)+(âˆ’âˆ’/âˆ’+)]P_{2}=\frac{1}{2}\big{[}(++/+-)+(--/-+)\big{]} (which also gives covCHSHâ€²=2superscriptcovCHSHâ€²2\text{covCHSH}^{\prime}=2, see Fig.Â 1)â€”where the notation (A0â€‹A1/B0â€‹B1)subscriptğ´0subscriptğ´1subscriptğµ0subscriptğµ1(A_{0}A_{1}/B_{0}B_{1}) denotes a strategy in which Alice and Bob deterministically output Axsubscriptğ´ğ‘¥A_{x} and Bysubscriptğµğ‘¦B_{y} for inputs xğ‘¥x and yğ‘¦y, respectively. In order to reach the local upper bound in Eq.Â (6), one needs to go to d=3ğ‘‘3d=3; the distribution POâ€‹pâ€‹t=37(++/++)+27(âˆ’+/âˆ’âˆ’)+27(âˆ’âˆ’/âˆ’+)P_{Opt}=\frac{3}{7}(++/++)+\frac{2}{7}(-+/--)+\frac{2}{7}(--/-+), for instance, gives covCHSH=167covCHSH167\text{covCHSH}=\frac{16}{7} (and covCHSHâ€²=1649superscriptcovCHSHâ€²1649\text{covCHSH}^{\prime}=\frac{16}{49}, see Fig.Â 1). One thus sees that reaching a given value of covCHSH requires mixing a certain number of deterministic strategies; this is an interesting feature, which will allow one to use the covariance inequality as a shared randomness witness (see below).

One may also look at possible violations of the covariance Bell inequalityÂ (6). One finds that it can indeed detect quantum nonlocality: that is, one can obtain covCHSH>167covCHSH167\text{covCHSH}>\frac{16}{7} by performing local measurements on an entangled state. For example, the quantum correlations that reach the maximal quantum value (the â€œTsirelson boundâ€Â Tsirelson ) of CHSH=2â€‹2222\sqrt{2} have vanishing marginals âŸ¨AxâŸ©=âŸ¨ByâŸ©=0delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğ´ğ‘¥delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğµğ‘¦0\langle A_{x}\rangle=\langle B_{y}\rangle=0, and therefore also give covCHSH=2â€‹2>167221672\sqrt{2}>\frac{16}{7} (point PQsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘„P_{Q} on Fig.Â 1). In fact, this is the largest possible quantum violation, as one can prove that all quantum correlations must satisfy the inequality

covCHSHâ‰¤2â€‹2.covCHSH22\text{covCHSH}\leq 2\sqrt{2}\,. (7)

This is shown in AppendixÂ B, where we also give a tighter characterization of the quantum set in terms of covariances. Note that in contrast to the local bound, marginals do not play any role in reaching the Tsirelson bound for covCHSH. Nevertheless, the nonlinearity of the Bell expression covCHSH also has interesting consequences in the quantum case. For instance, one can find two pure entangled states such that none of the states can individually violate the inequalityÂ (6), whereas a mixture of the two states can violate it; see AppendixÂ C for details.

Note, finally, that given the range of output variables, we have |covâ€‹(Ax,By)|â‰¤1covsubscriptğ´ğ‘¥subscriptğµğ‘¦1|\text{cov}(A_{x},B_{y})|\leq 1, and therefore the algebraic maximum possible value of covCHSH is 444 (just like for CHSH). This value can be reached by the non-signalling distribution known as the Popescu-Rohrlich (PR) nonlocal boxÂ PR (point PPâ€‹Rsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ƒğ‘…P_{PR} on Fig.Â 1), which again has vanishing marginals and also reaches the algebraic maximum of the CHSH expression.

Here the local bound was obtained through numerical optimization (up to machine precision); nevertheless, the reproducibility and reliability of the numerical results make us quite confident that the bound is correct. In AppendixÂ D we present local distributions that reach it, and discuss quantum and super-quantum (non-signalling) violations.

More generally, one may consider constructing covariance Bell inequalities following the above recipe, starting from an arbitrary linear Bell inequality with binary outcomes. Note that instead of simply dropping the marginal terms, one could as well keep them, or replace them with other functions, e.g. with variances.

Generalising even further our approach for covariance Bell inequalities, one can also investigate Bell inequalities based on Pearson correlators, which can be thought of as normalised covariances. Shared randomness witnesses.â€”

Let us come back now to covCHSH. As emphasized before, the value of covCHSH that can be obtained locally depends on the number of deterministic strategies involved in the local strategy being used. This readily allows one to obtain a lower bound on the classical dimension dğ‘‘d of the shared variable Î›Î›\Lambda (i.e., the number of different values it can take), or equivalently its max-entropy Hmaxâ€‹(Î›)â‰¡log2â¡dsubscriptğ»maxÎ›subscript2ğ‘‘H_{\text{max}}(\Lambda)\equiv\log_{2}d: from the discussion above, it follows that as soon as covCHSH>0covCHSH0\text{covCHSH}>0, one requires dâ‰¥2ğ‘‘2d\geq 2, i.e. Hmaxâ€‹(Î›)â‰¥1subscriptğ»maxÎ›1H_{\text{max}}(\Lambda)\geq 1; if covCHSH>2covCHSH2\text{covCHSH}>2, then dâ‰¥3ğ‘‘3d\geq 3, i.e. Hmaxâ€‹(Î›)â‰¥log2â¡3subscriptğ»maxÎ›subscript23H_{\text{max}}(\Lambda)\geq\log_{2}3.

For a given value of covCHSH between 00 and 167167\frac{16}{7}, one can also obtain a lower bound on Hâ€‹(Î›)ğ»Î›H(\Lambda) by minimizing it for all local strategies. As it turns out, it suffices to optimise Hâ€‹(Î›)ğ»Î›H(\Lambda) over decompositions onto deterministic strategies with binary outputs Â±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1â€”intuitively, local randomness does not help increase covCHSH. The details of our optimization are given in AppendixÂ E, and the results we obtained are plotted on Fig.Â 2. Unsurprisingly, we find that minâ¡Hâ€‹(Î›)ğ»Î›\min H(\Lambda) increases with the value of covCHSH. Thus covCHSH acts as a device-independent witness for characterizing the dimension and the entropy of the shared randomness of a local strategy in a Bell experiment. This complements recent works on device-independent tests of the dimension of quantum systemsÂ dimH , and of the dimensionÂ gallego and entropyÂ CBB of classical communications.

Discussion.â€”

In this Letter we introduced Bell inequalities based on covariances, a natural measure of correlations, rather than on linear combinations of probabilities. We presented the simplest example of such a covariance Bell inequality with binary inputs, that echoes the well-known CHSH inequality, and investigated some of its properties. Proving analytically the local bound is not straightforward here, due to the nonlinearity of the Bell expression, but we could nevertheless provide a method to do so. Its quantum bound was also proven analytically.

Beyond this simplest example, we proposed a general recipe to construct, from any standard Bell inequality with binary outcomes, new Bell inequalities for covariances as well as for Pearson correlators. While our analytical method for proving the local bound generalizes in principle to any covariance Bell inequality obtained with our construction, in practice it becomes intractable for larger numbers of inputs. Nevertheless, for the examples we presented the local bounds could reliably be obtained numerically. It would be interesting to find a more efficient way to prove local bounds, as well as quantum bounds, for covariance-based Bell inequalitiesâ€”or even to find other ways to characterize the local and quantum sets of admissible covariances (note that a tighter characterization of the quantum set than Eq.Â (7) can already be given, see AppendixÂ B). One possible idea would be to look for some hierarchy of criteriaâ€”similar in spirit to that of NavascuÃ©s-Pironio-AcÃ­n (NPA) for quantum correlationsâ€”that covariances must satisfy; indeed, one finds that covariances and Pearson correlators appear naturally in the NPA hierarchyÂ NPA .

An interesting feature of our covariance Bell inequalities is that they serve as a shared randomness witness. Indeed, in contrast with standard linear Bell inequalities where the local bound can always be attained by a single deterministic strategy, reaching the local boundâ€”or in fact, any nontrivial valueâ€”for a Bell expression defined in terms of covariances requires, for a local strategy, to make use of shared randomness. We showed explicitly, on our simplest example, how the value of the Bell expression allows one to place device-independent lower bounds on the amount of shared randomness in a local model (both in terms of its dimension and its entropy). Such witnesses may help addressing certain problems in quantum nonlocality related to shared randomnessÂ pal ; sikora ; vicente , in particular finding what is the minimal amount of shared randomness necessary to simulate the correlations of entangled states admitting a local modelÂ joe . Our example with binary inputs allows one to certify the use of relatively little shared randomness (e.g. a dimension of at least 333); it would be interesting to find (families of) covariance Bell inequalities that can certify larger amounts of shared randomness. While covariance Bell inequalities were found to provide a natural way to provide device-independent witnesses for shared randomness, such witnesses could also be studied in other frameworks, with other types of Bell inequalities that require shared randomness to be saturatedâ€”e.g. with entropic inequalitiesÂ bc ; cerf ; chaves .

From a more practical perspective, our covariance Bell inequality could be useful in experimental situations where access to measurement data is limited, e.g. if only covariances can be measured, and where standard Bell inequalities cannot be used. This could be relevant to certain mesoscopic electronics experimental setups. With such applications in mind, it would also be interesting to also investigate similar covariance inequalities to the ones constructed here for other types of quantum nonlocality, e.g. for entanglementÂ HHHH or quantum steeringÂ steering (we note that inequalities were constructed in these contexts for covariance matrices, although following very different approachesÂ WW ; giedke ; guehne ; jevtic ; maccone ).

Finally, Bell inequalities based on covariances could be useful for the study of nonlocal correlations in networks. When a network features several sources that are assumed to be independent, the set of local distributions (or rather, â€œNğ‘N-local distributionsâ€ for a network with Nğ‘N independent sources) is typically nonconvex, and nonlinear Bell inequalities are necessary to give an effective description of the (Nğ‘N-)local setÂ branciard ; biloc2 ; armin ; chaves16 ; rosset16 . In fact, some recent workÂ chaves17 has already made use of covariances in the context of quantum networks, however not constructing explicit Bell inequalities. The ideas developed here could also find some nice applications in providing ways to obtain new types of Bell inequalities, and possibly shared randomness witnesses, for networks.

Appendix A Proofs of the covariance Bell inequalityÂ (6)

Obtaining the local bound for a standard (linear) Bell inequality is rather straightforward, as one can simply focus on deterministic strategies. However, such an approach does not work for covariance Bell inequalities because of their nonlinearity.

In this Appendix we give the details of the proof of the inequalityÂ (6), as sketched in the main text. We then present an alternative proof that also uses Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) multipliers and conditionsÂ KKT , although in a different way. While the former can in principle be adapted to any other covariance Bell inequality (but may not actually be practical because of the very high number of cases to consider for increased numbers of parameters), the latter exploits specific properties of the CHSH (2-input / 2-output) scenario and uses fewer variables in the optimization; it is however less instructive with respect to the shared randomness required for obtaining a given value of covCHSH with a local model, and adapting it to another scenario will first require finding the right properties to exploit.

A.1 Optimizing over the weights of deterministic distributions

The proof here will be divided into three parts. The first one consists in showing that, without loss of generality, we can focus on a situation where only binary outputs are considered. The second part describes how standard methods for solving (quadratic) constrained problems can be applied. Finally, the third part shows how our quadratic problem can be simplified to a number of linear ones, and solved.

A.1.3 Reduction to linear systems of equations and resolution

Because of the constraint Î»kâ€‹qk=0subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0\lambda_{k}q_{k}=0, the above system of equations is nonlinear. One can however reduce it to a number of different linear systems of equations by imposing that a given subset of weigths qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k} take nonzero values, and by considering separately the case of each possible subset. For those qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k} in the given subset under consideration, the last line of Eq.Â (A.1.2) simply becomes Î»k=0,qk>0formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ†ğ‘˜0subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0\lambda_{k}=0,q_{k}>0, while for the other qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k}â€™s, it becomes qk=0,Î»kâ‰¥0formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜0q_{k}=0,\lambda_{k}\geq 0â€”with in both cases, Î»k=âˆ’Ckâ€‹k+âˆ‘iqiâ€‹(Ciâ€‹k+Ckâ€‹i)+Î¼subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜subscriptğ¶ğ‘˜ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ¶ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğœ‡\lambda_{k}=-C_{kk}+\sum_{i}q_{i}(C_{ik}+C_{ki})+\mu according to the first line of Eq.Â (A.1.2). For a given number dğ‘‘d of nonzero weights, the systemÂ (A.1.2) then reduces to d+1ğ‘‘1d+1 linear equality constraints and 161616 (also linear) inequality constraints (with dğ‘‘d strict and 16âˆ’d16ğ‘‘16-d nonstrict inequalities) for the remaining d+1ğ‘‘1d+1 nontrivial variables qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k} and Î¼ğœ‡\mu.

Note that if only d=1ğ‘‘1d=1 weight qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k} is nonzero (and therefore equal to 1), then the distribution Pâ€‹(a,b|x,y)ğ‘ƒğ‘conditionalğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦P(a,b|x,y) is deterministic, which implies that all covariancesâ€”and hence covCHSHâ€”are zero. Furthermore, as already mentioned previously, due to CarathÃ©odoryâ€™s theorem it is sufficient to only consider subsets with at most d=9ğ‘‘9d=9 (out of 161616) nonzero qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k}â€™sâ€”indeed, if a maximum is reached by some decomposition involving more than 999 deterministic distributions, then it is also reached by another decomposition giving the same distribution, but involving no more than 999 deterministic distributions. We used Mathematica to solve, for each value of dğ‘‘d between 222 and 999, the (16d)binomial16ğ‘‘\binom{16}{d} different linear systems of equations corresponding to all the different subsets containing dğ‘‘d nonzero weights (which makes a total of âˆ‘d=29(16d)=50â€‰626superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘29binomial16ğ‘‘50626\sum_{d=2}^{9}\binom{16}{d}=50\,626 linear systems to consider). More specifically, we first found the solutions that satisfy all equality constraints and then checked which ones also satisfy the inequality constraints. To obtain the local bound of our covariance Bell inequalityÂ (6), there then remains to check what is the largest possible value of covCHSH for all these feasible solutions.

For d=2ğ‘‘2d=2, all (162)=120binomial162120\binom{16}{2}=120 systems of equations have solutions that satisfy all equality constraints (out of which, 565656 have unique solutions and 646464 are still underdetermined), but only 444 out of them have (unique) solutions that also satisfy the inequality constraints. Those 444 solutions all give covCHSH=2covCHSH2\text{covCHSH}=2, which is the maximal value that one can reach by mixing only 222 local deterministic distributions.

With d=3ğ‘‘3d=3 nonzero weights qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k}, again all (163)=560binomial163560\binom{16}{3}=560 systems of equations have solutions that satisfy all equality constraints (432432432 with unique solutions and 128128128 still underdetermined), but only 888 of them have (unique) solutions that also satisfy the inequality constraints. Those solutions are listed in TableÂ 1; they all have the similar form P=37â€‹Pk1det+27â€‹Pk2det+27â€‹Pk3detğ‘ƒ37superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘˜1det27superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘˜2det27superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘˜3detP=\frac{3}{7}P_{k_{1}}^{\text{det}}+\frac{2}{7}P_{k_{2}}^{\text{det}}+\frac{2}{7}P_{k_{3}}^{\text{det}}, and all give the value covCHSH=167covCHSH167\text{covCHSH}=\frac{16}{7}.

As it turns out, this value of 167167\frac{16}{7} obtained by suitably mixing 3 deterministic local distributions cannot be increased by mixing more distributions. For d=4ğ‘‘4d=4 for instance, we find that out of the (164)=1â€‰820binomial1641820\binom{16}{4}=1\,820 systems of equations, only 1â€‰51615161\,516 have solutions that satisfy all equality constraints, out of which only 141414 have solutions that also satisfy the inequality constraints. 666 of these (still underdetermined) solutions give a local maximum of covCHSH=2covCHSH2\text{covCHSH}=2, while the other 888 (unique) solutionsâ€”all of the form P=38â€‹Pk1det+38â€‹Pk2det+18â€‹Pk3det+18â€‹Pk4detğ‘ƒ38superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘˜1det38superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘˜2det18superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘˜3det18superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘˜4detP=\frac{3}{8}P_{k_{1}}^{\text{det}}+\frac{3}{8}P_{k_{2}}^{\text{det}}+\frac{1}{8}P_{k_{3}}^{\text{det}}+\frac{1}{8}P_{k_{4}}^{\text{det}} (one solution being obtained for instance by taking Pk1det=(++/++),Pk2det=(âˆ’+/âˆ’âˆ’),Pk3det=(+âˆ’/âˆ’+)P_{k_{1}}^{\text{det}}=(++/++),P_{k_{2}}^{\text{det}}=(-+/--),P_{k_{3}}^{\text{det}}=(+-/-+) and Pk4det=(âˆ’âˆ’/âˆ’+)P_{k_{4}}^{\text{det}}=(--/-+))â€”give covCHSH=94covCHSH94\text{covCHSH}=\frac{9}{4}. The results for all values of dğ‘‘d from 222 to 999 are summarized in TableÂ 2. For d=6ğ‘‘6d=6 and 888, we also get local maxima of covCHSH=2covCHSH2\text{covCHSH}=2, while for d=5,7ğ‘‘57d=5,7 and 999, no solutions are found for any of the corresponding systems of KKT conditions. As one can see, the maximal value of covCHSH obtained for all cases is thus 167167\frac{16}{7}; this concludes the proof that this is indeed the value of the local bound in our covariance Bell inequalityÂ (6).

It should be clarified that although TableÂ 2 gives local maxima of 222 or 9494\frac{9}{4} for dâ‰¥4ğ‘‘4d\geq 4, this does not mean that those are the maximum values of covCHSH when mixing dâ‰¥4ğ‘‘4d\geq 4 deterministic local distributions. Indeed, the table gives local maxima obtained in a set delimited by strict inequalities qk>0subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0q_{k}>0, while the suprema over these sets may be obtained for some qkâ†’0â†’subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0q_{k}\to 0. In fact, covCHSH can get arbitrarily close to 167167\frac{16}{7} with a mixture of dâ‰¥4ğ‘‘4d\geq 4 deterministic local distributions by mixing an optimal decomposition with 333 distributions from TableÂ 1, with a tiny amount of dâˆ’3ğ‘‘3d-3 other distributions.

We are then left with just the last couple of lines of Eq.Â (15), so that either Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0 or CHSH=2CHSH2\text{CHSH}=2, and for each x,y,a,bğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘ğ‘x,y,a,b such that aâ€‹b=(âˆ’1)xâ€‹y+1ğ‘ğ‘superscript1ğ‘¥ğ‘¦1ab=(-1)^{xy+1}, either Î»xâ€‹yâ€‹aâ€‹b=0subscriptğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘ğ‘0\lambda_{xyab}=0 or Pâ€‹(a,b|x,y)=0ğ‘ƒğ‘conditionalğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦0P(a,b|x,y)=0. Using Mathematica we found feasible solutions for those equations in 320320320 of the 512512512 cases. However, one still needs to check if these solutions satisfy the remaining inequality constraints in Eq.Â (15); only in 207207207 of those cases could we find solutions that indeed satisfy all KKT conditions. Among all these solutions, we found that the maximal value of covCHSH was 167167\frac{16}{7}, which again proves that this is the local bound of our covariance Bell inequalityÂ (6). This value of 167167\frac{16}{7} was obtained for the 888 solutions listed in TableÂ 3, which indeed define the same 888 distributions as those listed (in the same order) in TableÂ 1.

A.3 Generalizing our proofs to other covariance Bell inequalities

The two versions of the proof of inequalityÂ (6) presented above could in principle be generalized to calculate the local bound of any covariance Bell inequality constructed from a linear Bell inequality with binary outcomes, following the recipe we suggest in the main text. However, as the number of inputs, and therefore the dimension of the relevant probability space, increase, the number of different cases to consider in the proof may become too large to be tractable in a reasonable time.

For the case of cov3322 with ternary inputs for instance, after reducing to binary outputs and taking into account normalization and non-signalling constraints, the relevant probability space is of dimension dimPâ†’=15subscriptdimâ†’ğ‘ƒ15\text{dim}_{\vec{P}}=15. Following the first approach for the proof above, local distributions can be decomposed onto the 26superscript262^{6} deterministic local distributions, and the number of different cases to consider (corresponding to the number of subsets of dğ‘‘d nonzero weights qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k}, with 2â‰¤dâ‰¤dimPâ†’+12ğ‘‘subscriptdimâ†’ğ‘ƒ12\leq d\leq\text{dim}_{\vec{P}}+1) is âˆ‘d=216(26d)â‰¥7Ã—1014superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘216binomialsuperscript26ğ‘‘7superscript1014\sum_{d=2}^{16}\binom{2^{6}}{d}\geq 7\times 10^{14}, a number far too large for all cases to be considered separately.

One may hope that following our second approach for the proof, instead, may reduce the number of cases to be considered down to a tractable one. The first thing to check here would be which constraints (locality constraints in terms of CHSH or I3322subscriptğ¼3322I_{3322} inequalities, together with non-negativity of the probabilities constraints) are sufficient to impose in order to obtain the local bound on cov3322. We did not follow this approach any further, and leave as an open question, whether this would be tractable enough to provide an analytical proof of inequalityÂ (9).

Instead, to obtain the local bound of inequalityÂ (9), we resorted to numerical optimization, by optimizing over the 26=64superscript26642^{6}=64 weights qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k} in a local decomposition of P=âˆ‘kqkâ€‹Pkdetğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜detP=\sum_{k}q_{k}P_{k}^{\text{det}}. Although the optimization problem is nonconvex and involves quite a few free parameters, we found that the result of the numerical optimization was stable enough when starting from different starting points, which makes us confident that the local bound of 9292\frac{9}{2} in inequalityÂ (9) is indeed correct.

We note, finally, that the same proof techniques as above do not work for Bell inequalities with Pearson correlators like inequalityÂ (10). The first point to be noticed is that, as emphasized before, the local sets for binary outputs a,bâˆˆ{+1,âˆ’1}ğ‘ğ‘11a,b\in\{+1,-1\} and for more outputs a,bâˆˆ[âˆ’1,+1]ğ‘ğ‘11a,b\in[-1,+1] are not the sameâ€”indeed we found different local bounds for binary and ternary outputs. Even restricting to a fixed number of inputs and trying to follow our approach with KKT multipliers, the Lagrangians we would write in either of the two proof versions would not be nicely quadratic functions of the weights qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k} in a local decomposition of the form P=âˆ‘qkâ€‹Pkdetğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜detP=\sum q_{k}P_{k}^{\text{det}} (as in Eq.Â (A.1.2)), or of the expectation values âŸ¨Axâ€‹ByâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğ´ğ‘¥subscriptğµğ‘¦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle, âŸ¨AxâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğ´ğ‘¥\langle A_{x}\rangle and âŸ¨ByâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğµğ‘¦\langle B_{y}\rangle (as in Eq.Â (A.2)), so that the KKT necessary conditions for linearity would not simplify to linear systems of equations. Instead of pursuing such an approach, we again resorted here to numerical optimizations. As before, the numerical results we obtained were stable enough to make us confident that the local bounds we give are correct.

Appendix B Tsirelson bounds and quantum violations for covCHSH and rCHSH

This bound can again be reached quantum mechanically, see below.

As just mentioned, here no restriction is imposed on the measurement outcomes (provided only that Ïƒâ€‹(Ax),Ïƒâ€‹(By)<âˆğœsubscriptğ´ğ‘¥ğœsubscriptğµğ‘¦\sigma(A_{x}),\sigma(B_{y})<\infty). (as well as the symmetrical inequalities).

B.3 Explicit quantum violations of inequalitiesÂ (6) andÂ (10)

The Tsirelson bounds for covCHSH and rCHSH can be reached by the same quantum mechanical correlations as those that reach the maximal quantum value of CHSH=2â€‹2CHSH22\text{CHSH}=2\sqrt{2}. In that case the marginal expectation values âŸ¨AxâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğ´ğ‘¥\langle A_{x}\rangle and âŸ¨ByâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğµğ‘¦\langle B_{y}\rangle vanish, so that covCHSH and rCHSH simply reduce to CHSH, and we indeed obtain covCHSH = rCHSH = CHSH = 2â€‹2222\sqrt{2}.

By then rotating for instance Bobâ€™s measurement settings together around the yğ‘¦y axis of the Bloch sphere, one obtains the full circle drawn on Fig.Â 1.

Let us finally mention that we also investigated quantum violations of inequalityÂ (6) using mixed entangled states of rank 3 and higher (up to dimension 6Ã—6666\times 6). Appendix D Optimal local strategies and violations for our covariance Bell inequalitiesÂ (9)â€“(10)

In this Appendix we present some local strategies that reach the local bounds of our Bell inequalitiesÂ (9) andÂ (10), and show how these can be violated quantum mechanically and by non-signalling correlations. Recall that the local bounds were obtained numerically; however, we are confident that the numerics are trustworthy enough, and therefore that the local strategies we present below are indeed optimal.

D.1 Covariance Bell inequalityÂ (9)

D.1.1 Optimal local strategies

To obtain the local bound for cov3322 we ran a numerical optimization several times and conclude from the stability of the result that it must be 9292\frac{9}{2}, as in inequalityÂ (9).

There are 4 different local distributions that give the value cov3322=92cov332292\text{cov3322}=\frac{9}{2}, and that decompose onto three deterministic correlations with weights 3838\frac{3}{8}, 3838\frac{3}{8} and 1414\frac{1}{4}: namely, P=38(+++/+++)+38(âˆ’âˆ’+/âˆ’âˆ’+)+14(âˆ’+âˆ’/âˆ’+âˆ’)P=\frac{3}{8}(+++/+++)+\frac{3}{8}(--+/--+)+\frac{1}{4}(-+-/-+-), P=38(+++/++âˆ’)+38(âˆ’âˆ’+/âˆ’âˆ’âˆ’)+14(+âˆ’âˆ’/âˆ’++)P=\frac{3}{8}(+++/++-)+\frac{3}{8}(--+/---)+\frac{1}{4}(+--/-++) (using here the notation (A0â€‹A1â€‹A2/B0â€‹B1â€‹B2)subscriptğ´0subscriptğ´1subscriptğ´2subscriptğµ0subscriptğµ1subscriptğµ2(A_{0}A_{1}A_{2}/B_{0}B_{1}B_{2})), and the other 2 â€œopposite decompositionsâ€, where all outputs are flipped.

D.2.2 Optimal local strategies with ternary outputs a,b=+1,0,âˆ’1formulae-sequenceğ‘ğ‘101a,b=+1,0,-1

As emphasized before, in the case of Pearson correlators, considering binary outputs or a larger alphabet of possible outputs does make a difference. As shown in AppendixÂ B.2, the value of rCHSH, for any choice of possible outputs, that can be reached locally is upper-bounded by 2â€‹2222\sqrt{2}. As it turns out, this bound can be reached with ternary outputs a,b=+1,0,âˆ’1formulae-sequenceğ‘ğ‘101a,b=+1,0,-1, for instance by the local distribution P=49(++/+0)+49(+âˆ’/0+)+19(00/âˆ’âˆ’)P=\frac{4}{9}(++/+0)+\frac{4}{9}(+-/0+)+\frac{1}{9}(00/--).

This implies that rCHSH defined in Eq.Â (10) contains at most 2 nonzero Pearson correlators, which implies that rCHSHâ‰¤2rCHSH2\text{rCHSH}\leq 2. Furthermore, if the two output variables of any party are both deterministic, then rCHSH=0rCHSH0\text{rCHSH}=0. Nevertheless, one can also locally reach a value of rCHSH arbitrarily close to the bound 2â€‹2222\sqrt{2} by certain distributions that get arbitrarily close to some deterministic ones: e.g., P=(1âˆ’Ïµ)(++/+0)+Ïµ2(+âˆ’/âˆ’+)+Ïµ2(âˆ’+/âˆ’âˆ’)P=(1-\epsilon)(++/+0)+\frac{\epsilon}{2}(+-/-+)+\frac{\epsilon}{2}(-+/--) with 0<Ïµ<10italic-Ïµ10<\epsilon<1 gives rCHSH=2â€‹(1+1âˆ’Ïµ)/2âˆ’Ïµâ†’2â€‹2rCHSH211italic-Ïµ2italic-Ïµâ†’22\text{rCHSH}=2(1+\sqrt{1-\epsilon})/\sqrt{2-\epsilon}\to 2\sqrt{2} as Ïµâ†’0â†’italic-Ïµ0\epsilon\to 0 (note that Alice still has a binary output Â±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1 here; only Bob has a ternary output +1,0,âˆ’1101+1,0,-1, for one of his inputs only). Hence, in this case the value of rCHSH cannot be used as a shared randomness witness.

D.2.3 Violations of inequalityÂ (10)

As proven in AppendixÂ B, the Tsirelson bound for rCHSH is 2â€‹2222\sqrt{2}, which can be reached by adequate (binary) projective measurements on a maximally 2-qubit entangled states. The quantum correlations thus obtained thus violate the inequalityÂ (10) (with the local bound 5252\frac{5}{2}, for the case where one restricts to binary outputs), but do not violate the analogous inequality for arbitrary outcomes, when the local bound also becomes 2â€‹2222\sqrt{2} (see above).

We note that for rCHSH, the nonlinearity of the Bell expression does not seem to exhibit the same interesting features as covCHSH and cov3322 presented in the previous appendices: the maximal value of a mixture of pure states appears, from our numerical investigations, to always be attained by one of the pure states.

Finally, note that algebraic maximum of rCHSH=4 can be obtained by a PR box (just as for CHSH and covCHSH).
